Comment: One of the reasons that tax breaks keep getting created and that it's so hard to get rid of them is that so many already exist.  Each special interest has a point when they say "Hey, you gave XXX tax exemption, so it's only fair we get one too!".  And it's a pretty valid point.  It's unfair to create such inconsistent tax treatment, and it gives each special interest a justification for getting theirs too.

We need to wipe them ALL out (and lower the base rates accordingly).  That way everyone is paying their fair share, and no one can point to the other and say it's unfair for someone else to get an exemption without them getting theirs too.  And it needs to be an "all at once" effort so people understand that EVERYONE will be paying their fair share once the changes are implemented. 

Even worse is the federal tax code.  That needs to be wiped clean and started over as well, with NO deductions/breaks/credits and a lowering of the base rates.

Comment: The city isn't responsible for downtown's revival. It revived only because the city's main efforts were stopped. The public voted to take away the city's borrowing authority for downtown in 2007 (ballot measure 20-134). Defunding this 'urban renewal' authority changed the game for property owners. They could no longer let their buildings fall apart and wait for a big urban renewal project payday. So they started to actually work with their tenants, or sell buildings they didn't want to fix. Taking the city's money away allowed downtown to revive for the first time in decades, even during an economic recession.

Comment: I had two kids prone to tantrums. I could never get them to sit in time-outs. I was totally against spanking at the time. Comment: When you cut funding for a school, programs are cut, and teachers wither. Education is at stake. So, people go to schools that offer what they want. As Mr. Cranor said below, these are usually students with better-off parents, leaving the poor kids behind. Meanwhile, Marist (just across the river) offers North-region students sports/academic scholarships, increasing transfer #'s. The district notices a decline in enrollment and cuts more. The same process continues. It doesn't end. And it won't. Unless 4J halts the ability for some schools (South Eugene) to flourish while others (North Eugene) scramble to handle cuts in staff and budget. 

Clair Wiles put it perfectly. School choice is segregation, absolutely. Ms. Dragt is absolutely justified in her concerns for a shutdown, because it won't change without action. 

I urge the school board to eliminate school choice and to focus on providing a truly equitable experience for students at all 4 high schools.

Comment: In 2007, the Sarkozy and his Union for a Popular Movement won the presidency. But what was the Union for a Popular Movement? A new major party, kind of. It was a merger of Rally for the Republic (formed in 1976 after the dissolution of the Union of Democrats for the Republic), the Liberal Democracy party, and parts of the Union for French Democracy (formed 1978, dissolved, 2007).  So it was that a major party or a new party? 

So while Emmanuel Macron's EnMarche! represents a new party in that there are no clear precedent parties and mergers, Macron himself is a former member of the Socialist party and has drawn in people from other parties. He is trying to create a stable centrist faction rather than the pull and push between the many iterations of the Gaullists, conservatives and socialists.
Ultimately, he is trying to establish a 'centre' that arguably has never existed in France in terms of shifting dominant political parties and factions. French politics has always been radical.

Comment: We're on the dawn of Canada's 150th birthday. In 1967, ice arenas popped up all across our country, thanks to federal grants for the 100th birthday celebrations. Many of those arenas are in extremely small communities -- the social wintertime hub -- only kept alive through the efforts of volunteers and the aggressive fundraising they do. 

These small communities would love to cut their energy bills down by using reclaim heat from their compressors, cold water technologies for flooding their ice, swapping energy inefficient metal halide lights for LED or T12 fluorescent -- but many have bigger problems to solve before doing that -- like fixing their leaking roofs. There should be a Federal program set up to fix these old barns properly -- not with patchwork solutions -- and then an energy-efficient mandate implemented. 

Talk to your MP.

Comment: The Institute of Traffic Engineers (ITE) estimates a typical single-family dwelling generates an average of 10 trips/day (1 trip=1 segment of a round-trip). By that measure, these two developments, if built with single family homes, will add between 6,000 to 7,000 additional trips to the transportation network. The Ferry Street Bridge carries in excess of 40,000 vehicles per day. Imagine traffic equivalent to 15-17% of the Ferry St. Bridge traffic being dumped on to Beltline/Delta interchange without any improvements to the current infrastructure. Since traffic, like water, seeks its on level, you can bet that, w/o needed improvements, trips generated by these new homes will impact other travel corridors (Ayres, Gilham, Crest, Norkenzie, Cal Young, Oakway and Coburg). Add that public transit options for this area are limited and you have a mess. No further development should be allowed until Delta/Beltline improvements are made.
But Ayres area residents already know this.

Comment: Other teams now use the Oregon read option to one degree or another and thus practice against it weekly all season long.  This practice allows defenders to learn the intercept angles necessary to make solid tackles and linemen learn how to defeat the blocking.  This eliminates the big advantage Oregon used to have, that being the element of teams being unfamiliar with the offense with only one week to prepare for it.  Competitors have also adopted the "Tempo" , use it regularly and thus are in better shape to slow it down. Linebackers are smaller and faster and quicker thanks to Oregon"s scheme and reduce the effectiveness of the Oregon scheme. Essentially, Oregon has taught their competitors how to defend them as most have copied parts of their offense.  Oregon has taught competitors how to beat them.  The scheme also requires a very skilled QB with a very high  accuracy and fast feet. These are very hard to find. Recruit some bigger lineman would help, as Oregon undersized on line.

Comment: The press getting hysterical about the "Lock her up" chant is funny. Why is anyone interpreting hyperbole at political rallies  so literally? Did Trump lock up Hillary? No. Did it ever mean lock her up arbitrarily without a trial? I don't think so, it was hyperbole for "prosecute her".

A common chant at political protests in Quebec for decades has been "X, au poteau!", meaning literally "X, to the post", i.e. the execution post. Did anyone actually mean "kill X"? In the heat of the moment, some maybe, but was it ever taken literally? I doubt it.

It is also bizarre considering that there is a long tradition of burning politicians, etc. in effigy at political protests. How is this any different, particularly since "locking someone up" is  lot less extreme than burning them or calling for their execution.

More concerning is people *actually getting fired* for having the wrong opinion. That is something happening for real.

I agree that access to affordable dental care for all is in need of vast improvement.  However, fluoridation is the most cost-effective means available to prevent dental decay in entire populations.  Until access can be improved, we can't afford to eliminate any viable  preventive measures.

In advocating for fluoridation, I do so after having spent the overwhelming part of my 30+ year dental career in providing dental care for low-income, and indigents, both in my private practice and a large free portable dental program I founded.  I have done all I can to provide for the underserved population.

Antifluoridationists  on the other hand, do their utmost to undermine this dental infection preventive measure, while having done not one single thing to provide for the underserved, and providing no viable alternatives to replace fluoridation.  They simply do their damage, then callously move on, leaving locals to deal with the mess they've left.
.

Comment: The RCMP are arresting and detaining them under the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act and turning them over to Canada Immigration for processing.

There is a very good legal reason why refugee claimants (not asylum seekers which are a completely different class of persons) are not being charged in respect of their entry to Canada.

Under Article 31 of the 1951 Convention on Refugees Canada has undertaken to not prosecute refugee claimants for illegal entry into Canada including any issues of false documents or fraud relating to that entry.

Canada has enacted that exemption into our domestic law as required by the Convention in various iterations of our immigration legislation over the years. Currently that exemption is contained at s. 133 of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act.

So no charges because the law exempts refugees recognizing that refugees who are fleeing persecution are different from other migrants.

Comment: Still not secure - email I got from Foscam - dated June 12 2017
The vulnerabilities affect "Foscam" branded cameras and cameras manufactured by China-based Shenzhen Foscam only. The vulnerabilities DO NOT affect Amcrest or FDT branded cameras which are produced by a separate factory and R&D team led by US-based Amcrest (formerly Foscam US and now Amcrest), which is totally unrelated to China-based Shenzhen Foscam. 

Amcrest split off from China-based Shenzhen Foscam in 2015 / 2016 due to issues relating to distribution, lack of security and quality control and thus Amcrest and FDT cameras are totally unaffected by these latest security vulnerabilities.

We recommend disconnecting your current Foscam branded cameras from the internet until these issues have been resolved. If you have any questions, please reach out to China-based Shenzhen Foscam directly.

https://arstechnica.com/security/2017/06/internet-cameras-expose-private-video-feeds-and-remote-controls

Comment: Actually, that sounds like a fine and just idea. Instead of filling prisons with people (and these kids would be there for five or six decades) and providing very high paying jobs for people who enjoy subjugating others in a controlled environment, we could actually teach these young thugs a thing or two and make an old man's injury mean something.

My mother's tribe used to do that sort of punishment - make you responsible for the family of the man you killed, make you work to pay for the property you destroyed, that sort of thing. Historic accounts say it worked pretty well, especially since -- at least initially -- you were ostracized from pretty much any other community activities. You were essentially a slave for a period of time and then, as you proved you could be trusted, you were given more freedom. As a rehabilitation tool, it seems to have worked much better than our current incarceration system that just teaches people how to be better criminals.

Comment: Europeans have only been here 200 years.  Tree rings and forest patterns suggest that there have been other periods of high temps, fires,   and much colder,  drier weather.  Reliable thermometers have only been around for a century at most.  In that time,  long time weather stations have been encompassed by expanding urbanization, putting  them in a zone of air conditioning putting hot air into the atmosphere along with millions of tons of asphalt, concrete,  masonry to create thermal inertia.  Living in a brick house,  I know  it is slow to warm,  and slow to cool.  I call it "coasting."  Long after the heat wave is gone,  the house is still warm on the upper story.  The daylight basement stays cool from the cement floor in summer,  and warmer in winter due to the same inertia of the concrete and earth below.

Comment: Real estate is a great investment tool, and it always will be due to the appreciation.  Furthermore, basic economics (supply and demand) drives this market.

This is mainly because (as I've said) due to ultra tight environmental ordinances which employer's can not operate under.  The problem is not low wages, landlords, but instead a very soft family wage job market.  

Raising the minimum wage and rent control simple won't solve a thing, it would probably make things worse.  What Eugene needs is more $15-20/hour jobs.

Comment: Way to sit on the fence there Globe. Your focus on resources no doubt intentionally ignores the more compelling and difficult questions, such as how and whether Canada denies entry to those fleeing the U.S. because of their criminal conduct in that country. 

Not everyone seeking refuge is a refugee (i.e. do not come from a designated refugee producing region) and not everyone is of the character we would want in this country. 

There is absolutely no merit in the Globe's argument that Canada should ignore the loophole in the Safe Third Country Agreement that allows refugees and others to cross into the country illegally in order to escape scrutiny at border crossings. 

We should be compassionate and accommodating toward legitimate law abiding refugees, but we need to be equally determined to screen out and keep out undesirables. We shouldn't allow ourselves to become a dumping ground for those who've worn out their welcome in the U.S. because of their failure to obey its laws.

Comment: Wapiti,
I have it in writing from Treasury Board, that workers in the public sector receive the same total compensation as workers in the private sector, for similar work.

 If pensions are not indexed then the employer is taking the money generated by high interest caused by inflation. Additionally all pensions which are based on an average salary are less than what they appear. For example 30 years work results in a 60% pension. Retiring this year the purchasing power would be about 56% of the purchasing power in the averaging years. In 1981, in a period of high inflation, a 60% pension purchases 44% of that average purchasing power. 

There is a lot of misinformation about employer sponsored pensions. It has been spewing out for at least 36 years. So it is now regarded as truth.

Comment: When I was pastor of a parish church with a conservative order of nuns running the parochial school, I had a frequent debate with the principal. Her contention was that sacraments were for people who followed Church teachings very closely. (She passed over* children for First Communion if their families didn't attend Sunday Mass regularly. That's one example.) I said people never come where they're not wanted. If we didn't find a way to welcome people to the altar or the Baptismal font, they could never appreciate the richness of the Gospel. As a matter of fact, we never missed the chance to baptize a baby no matter the parents' circumstances. I'd see some of them in church after that.

Imagine the principal's surprise and anger when children she pushed out of the parochial school came to the sacraments through our Religious Ed department. Most of them continued to bring their parents to church after that. We need the biggest net we can find.

*yes, I used "passed over" deliberately.

Comment: "Crazy" and similar terms ("mad," "insane") as epithets for something or someone that seems far beyond the reasonable is probably as old as language itself.  The idiom can be found many times in  Greek tragedy.  I assume it's in the Bible, but I haven't specifically looked for it. It's in the Quran.  It's in Shakespeare and Milton.  In modern discourse, it's commonplace to call Hitler "insane" (which he wasn't in any clinical sense, except possibly for Parkinsonism).  

While Kennedy is right that people suffering from mental illness should not be associated with an idiom of opprobrium, the fact is that "crazy" and its synonyms have no scientific or clinical meaning.  They are popularly understood in a non-clinical sense.  While the "Political Correctness" meme is a poisonous one, it's possible to be ridiculous in our desire to sterilize ordinary language--which is, wonderfully, as various and unpredictable as people themselves are.

Comment: The facts: the area within which humans will be vaporized in a nuclear detonation is a small fraction of the area within which they will be at danger. For many people, taking cover would be a prudent and effective response.

Within a limited radius of the detonation, humans may be vaporized. Outside this radius, there would be an extreme heat wave that would burn people to death. Outside that radius would be a vast area that would be affected by a blast wave not very different from the blast wave of a conventional explosive. Taking cover to avoid falling debris is your best strategy in a blast wave. The subsequent effects of nuclear radiation are harder to predict. They depend on topology, weather, public health, etc.   

Crawling under the heaviest object in sight may not save your life. But if everybody does it, it will save a lot of lives. Disparaging it earns liberal applause, but only at the expense of irresponsibly teaching falsehoods about efficacious civil defense measures.

Comment: The rules are being abruptly changed.  It will affect physicians that were about to retire and may not be able to. Those that have already retired could be in trouble. 

Ontario docs have been without a fee increase for 5 years and fees have been reduced by 4.5% (at a minimum) compared to 2012.  Some fees have been cut in half, none have increased.  Other provinces have managed to increase fees over the same period. 

Physician incorporation with limited income splitting was negotiated in good faith and granted to physicians in exchange for fee increases about 15 years ago. The government set the rules and now they are reneging. This is the primary retirement savings vehicle for over 60% of physicians. 

Physicians are right to be upset. Most will stay in Canada, but not all. I will wait until the details are finalized.

Comment: Nothing wrong requiring the majority of the members of an HOA to approve of moving forward with litigation.  This bit of legislation is directly related to a tactic used by the Lawyers. Comment: Dutch politics can be difficult to understand, because there are so many parties.

It's true that the Freedom Party (PVV) increased its number of seats, and that the Labour Party (PvdA) lost a huge number of seats.

However, the Socialist Party, which is to the left of the Labour Party, held steady, and both the GreenLeft Party and the pro-EU D66 had a bigger increase than the PVV did. As well, a new left-wing, pro-tolerance party called Denk is projected to win three seats.

Overall, Saunders's comment about "the limits of the far-right populist movement" seems reasonable.

Comment: This can be confusing because everyone seems to have their own point of reference. You are correct that Juneau clock time now is closely equal to solar time during winter (Alaska Standard Time). During the summer now (under Alaska Daylight Savings Time) Anchorage is 2 hours ahead and Juneau is 1 hour ahead from solar time. Under MacKinnon's bill this relationship would remain and Juneau would be on same clock time as the west coast in the winter (when the west coast "falls back") but be one hour ahead of solar time. Central Alaska would be 2 hours ahead of solar time year-round. Ironically, back when Southeast was on Pacific Time for "convenience" sake, they were 1 hour ahead of solar time in the winter and 2 hours ahead during Daylight savings time in the summer. There is actually only a 1 hour 2 minute difference in solar time between Juneau and Anchorage. I hope I didn't make this more confusing - LOL

Comment: Any new line terminating at Glennallen would have to find a transmission connection. 115kV or 138kV at either an MEA substation or GVEA (Delta Junction). It's not remotely likely that any new line would be erected to connect Tok and/or Dot Lake. It's not an economic reality.

In the spring/summer of 1987, I flew the entire route of the pictured transmission line -- Glennallen to Valdez -- in a helicopter looking for lightning induced damage to transmission appurtenances*. The route was flown down and back with the chief engineer of CVEA, Frank Bettine. I was the operating manager of the line & the hydro plant at Solomon Gulch -- for the old Alaska Power Authority (APA).
-----
* Insulators; marker balls; crossarms.

Comment: The main problem with this leadership process is that Canadian parties have switched from the British model to the American one.  That gives rank and file members the say. The British model is beautiful in that it gives MPs the choice alone - they are the ones who work with these people on a daily basis and know full-well their strengths and weaknesses.  The all-members vote method (even at conventions by delegates) usually produces the wrong leaders...for example, Joe Clark or Stephane Dion.  The natural leader within caucus is the one who should get the nod.  They will have the smarts, personal habits, respect and style to achieve consensus within the group and recharge it moving forward in a way that will be respected over a long period, sufficient to get the leaderless party on back track.

Comment: I fail to see how blockchain is a threat to the principles of double entry book keeping which are based on the idea that you can't do any transaction without simultaneously adjusting both an asset account and a liability/equity account. That concept has inherent conceptual merit in simply understanding what you are doing, which goes beyond having a system for recording transactions. No doubt some interesting and challenging possibilities are ahead. I agree the potential benefits in greater efficiency are at risk of ever being seen by ordinary folks. This is the kind of thing that requires a strong government hand even as our government is patently already in the hands of the much coddled financial industry. In the good old days, government could borrow from the Bank of Canada. Pierre Trudeau fixed that. Popular sentiment is now being weaned away from valuing government at all. This is self defeating as a movement but music to the ears for the puppet masters of the private sector.

Comment: I've always said we have more in common than not, and I know you mean well. I agree that pleasure is fleeting and true joy comes from a much less superficial place. I think of marijuana like guns. You can find plenty of extremists who want to see guns banned at almost every level. I disagree with this. Guns have practical purposes, they are used for recreation, and they can also be extremely dangerous if put in the wrong hands or abused. I think the vast majority of gun owners are peaceful responsible people. As a society we need to mitigate areas of clear harm and pin point problems where they exist, rather than with broad correlation and prohibition. My well-intentioned opinion is that these compound the issues. Guns don't cause crime, people do. Removing the guns doesn't fix the people.

The problem hasn't yet "returned", but shoot them anyway so it won't.

Comment: So what's going on is that the Pacific Decadal Oscillation has been running positive for the past year and a half. When this happens, the Aleutian low is pretty weak and the panhandle ends up getting a lot cold and wet air from the north. Combined with climate change, you get an extra boost in moisture and the associated snowfall.

Comment: If these legislators (and the press) would bother to read Joint Uniform Legislative Rule 24 they would understand that no single committee can "kill" a bill.   Of course they do it all the time because Rules are for the little people aren't they? 

Excerpt from Rule 24. (Committee Referral and Action.)

(a) A committee acts on all bills referred to it and reports its actions and recommendations to the house as soon as practicable. Committee reports must be in writing and the report must be signed by a majority of the members of the committee. The report will note the recommendation of each member signing the report.

(b) When a bill is reported back by a committee without at least one "Do Pass", unless the bill has a subsequent referral or referrals of record, the presiding officer shall put the question "Shall the bill be referred to the Rules Committee for placement on the calendar for second reading notwithstanding the report of the committee(s)?

Comment: Trump brings to the presidency a unique combination of arrogance, ignorance, bigotry, incompetence, and emotional instability. He is a president-elect who is manifestly unfit to be president. I think Fr. Reese is right that many people have reacted to the election by moving through the stages of grief. I think it is important, though, that we don't get stuck in denial. There are two ways (at least) in which denial can get in our way as we go forward: 
1.) We can't deny the fact that this man has been elected. For sure, we need to study the election and understand what happened. But we have to accept the outcome.
2.) We can't deny or minimize how dangerously incompetent the president-elect is. We can't indulge a thought that begins with "Maybe it won't be so bad." We need to trust our Constitution and our democratic institutions, believing that they are sturdy enough to restrain and contain the worst impulses of this reckless, dangerous man. But we can't deny how dangerous he is.

Comment: Unfortunately, you chose an elderly patient who spoke no English as an example. This enabled many to sidetrack the "elderly terminal health care issue" to the "elderly family reunification immigration issue". 

I have faced the issue of looking after terminally ill relatives twice. The first time, my mother wished to die at home. So, my brother, brother-in-law and I made arrangements to become "night nurses" sharing the rotation 7 nights a week supplemented by "home care" visits from an Ontario paid health worker from 9:30 am to 4:30 pm each week day for her final 5 weeks. It was a strain; but one that was special as mom and I shared many memories of the family.

The second time was caring for my mother's 97 year old, very frail, cousin. She, too, wished to end her days in her own home. She eventually required re-hospitalization due to acute infection and died there. Family can do a lot; but not everything.

More discussion of solutions "fair" to hospitals / families are warranted.

Comment: Absolutely agreed.

Both assault and sexual assault see some common issues that work directly against getting convictions.  In both crimes, alcohol is involved in a gross majority of the cases, undermining the quality of testimony, substantially. In both crimes, the vast majority produce no corroborating physical evidence because there's no injuries. 98% of all sexual assaults reported last year had no injuries (type 1), for example. In addition, there's 3rd party witnesses in only a small fraction of the cases for both crimes.  There's generally slightly better chances for witnesses and visible injuries with assault, so the conviction rate is slightly higher, on average, but neither crime sees greater than half of the court cases get a guilty verdict.

Comment: Maybe some groups find it difficult to condone effective forms of management.  I recall growing up in Orange County, NY there was not a deer management problem because just about every male took to the woods during the deer season. Now fast forward.  Hardly anyone hunts anymore due to urban expansion and the cost of belonging to an established hunting club. Over the years dairy farms increased production and grew succulent crops to feed the cows.  The deer population exploded. There are now deer in the cemeteries, deer in the play grounds, deer on  the village greens, deer and more deer in the fields enjoying the fine food right along side the dairy cows.  There are so many deer that the coyote have returned and reproduced by the numbers.  So, once where deer were hunted and coyotes nonexistent (just well hidden) for well over one hundred years, both are now as common as doves in your front yard after putting out grass seed. As a result NY begs for deer hunters.

Comment: I'm not sure 'control' is a good description of Common Core, although some southern states complained about tightening up their standards.  One of the factors contributing to student failure is the difference in curriculum from state to state, district to district.  A student moving from one district to another risks missing whole concepts; a lot of time is lost just matching up with curriculum.  I've taught Middle School Math for roughly 30 years, and  seen it happen repeatedly.  Once continuity is interrupted it's hard to catch up.   

Common Core Curriculum is meant to provide some continuity.  Districts have the autonomy to decide how they comply, but are held accountable to the standard.  The Math texts are rigorous, introducing algebraic concepts as early as first grade, and students enjoy the challenge.

Comment: Healthcare is what you do to take care of yourself. 

The press keeps calling a financial product, health insurance, "healthcare". Health insurance is NOT healthcare. It is a financial product that may insure you from financial ruin, but it is not healthcare--and the ACA was never affordable. My husband and I were quoted over $24k for Obamacare coverage. 

We are currently uninsured--but that does not mean that we are without healthcare from doctors, dentists, and other professionals--it simply means that we pay out of our pockets.

The politicians and press are lying to you when they say that the ACA is healthcare. It is a method to force you to buy something that you may never need. It is a tax. Those who got financial benefit feel they are entitled to something that isn't free--but is taxpayer supported.

BTW: my husband and I take much better care of ourselves, and make much better life choices, so we avoid the medical professionals/

Comment: Not really.  The battery charging from brake energy recapture essentially offsets the extra energy required to haul around all those heavy batteries. Decent savings in the city (10-15%) - almost none on the highway.   And the guy who says the electric engine does most of the work on acceleration is just wrong.  That is when the gas engine is definitely engaged.

The very word "war" express the idea of violent and mortal conflict.

To say that any proposed war is just is to imply that not waging such a war is unjust. Therefore to avoid the unjust act of remaining neutral, one must do the "just" thing by going to war. It is partly why conscientious objectors are almost universally despised in wartime, because they are perceived as moral, intellectual and emotional cowards.

Comment: You are entitled to disagree, and I support that right, but I think we are on the same page.  I am saying that the protection offered by the "Freedom From Religion" interpretation means that you cannot legally be compelled to endorse or support a religion (or no religion) that conflicts with your own belief (or lack of belief).  You are correct to say it is not possible to avoid all exposure, but in those circumstances where a religious belief is being thrust at you in an inappropriate environment you are within your rights to oppose it and demand that it not be allowed to continue.

If, for example, you are a follower of religion A, you cannot be legally forced to endorse or support religion B.  Further, the government is not allowed to show favoritism toward any one religion over another.  Given the number of religions in the world, the only clear path to equal time for all religions is to allow no time for any of them, where the government is concerned. Personal piety is different.

Comment: There are many reasons why people try drugs. Teenagers with ADHD often try them if their condition has gone unrecognised or if prescription drugs have been unhelpful. It has been known for years that street drugs often help them feel better, but as their bodies become tolerant to the drugs they become addicted like anyone else. Adults often try them because of divorce, or money problems, or just because life is sh**ty and they think it will help them feel better. Musicians and artists are tempted to try them because it makes them feel more creative. They're all equally at risk to slide into addiction. 

It's easy to be dismissive and judgemental if you never knew these people before addiction and have never known an addict. But the fact is these people are sick. And the mark of a civilised society is that it looks after the worst-off in society and doesn't just discard them. And some - even the worst - are salvageable. So I support safe injection sites.

Comment: Actually it's about both. Our per capita emissions are high for all the reasons stated by others but they could be markedly reduced if we really tried. Comment: A German research team  has demonstrated that CB-2 receptor activation restrsains the formation of bone reabsorbing cells known as osteoclasts, by down-regulating osteoclast precursors, thus tipping the scale in favour of osteoblasts, cells that facilitate bone formation.

CB receptor signaling modulates pain and analgesia, inflammation, appetite, gastrointestinal motility, neuroprotection and neurodegeneration, along with the ebb and flow of immune cells, hormones, and other mood-altering neurotransmitters like serotonin, dopamine, and glutamate. When tickled by THC or its endogenous cousins, cannabinoid receptors trigger a cascade of biochemical changes on a cellular level that put the brakes on excessive physiological activity [cannabinoids---endo, herbal, and synthetic---are anti-inflammatory; they literally cool the body] (213, Smoke Signals by Martin A. Comment: One of my friends moved to Nova Scotia when she retired and loves it. Another friend is considering retiring in Newfoundland, where he was born and raised. His pension money will go a lot further there, he says. As for restaurants, perhaps you're correct about some areas (maybe in the suburbs?) but not where I live. My favourite Thai restaurant recently closed. My favourite Mexican restaurant closed. My favourite Lebanese restaurant closed. And several others have closed too, or are rumoured to be on the brink of doing so, lost to high rents or condo construction and seldom replaced. The little independent stores are gone or leaving as well, for the same reasons. The new condo podiums feature rents too expensive for anything other than chain outlets. As for good jobs, government stats show that Toronto, once a solidly middle class city, is now the poorest city in Canada in terms of child poverty and the extent of its low income neighbourhoods. It's pretty bleak here.

Comment: Donald Trump may prove to be the 'Gong Show President' but,  unless he does something far more egregious than implementing a temporary ban on Muslim immigration, he is likely to remain in office until the end of his term. He was elected by people who wished to express their dissatisfaction with both the Republican and Democrat establishments in Washington. He promised he would implement his platform prior to the election, was elected on the strength of his promises and is now delivering on them. Although opposition to him and to his promises was strong, it was not strong enough to convince those wishing for change to reject him. Opposition to him is still strong as the polling indicates but there is no evidence that his core support is dwindling. What is evident is that political polarity increasing given many conservatives and liberals cannot find consensus. Division is solidifying and the rancour is becoming more pronounced. Comment: There is no issue under the Privileges and Immunities Clause of Article IV. The Privileges and Immunities protections you mention make sure that Nevada cannot refuse to recognize a marriage license issued in California. Additionally, if a Nevada resident calls the police while visiting her boyfriend at Berkeley, the police cannot refuse to answer the call because of the caller's residency status. 

You certainly don't get the same rights. A resident of California, for example, is allowed to pay in-state tuition to attend Berkeley while a Nevada resident is not. 

There is, however, likely a problem with the Dormant Commerce Clause, and there are certainly Equal Protection Issues.

Comment: If a law is to legitimately infringe on a Charter right it must, first and foremost, address a substantive and pressing problem. This is the first step of the "Oakes Test"- the blueprint the Supreme Court uses to resolve such cases. Assuming a law does address a serious problem- which the Quebec law does not- then the law must also be rationally connected to that problem; enact restrictions that are proportionate; and must minimally impair any rights and freedoms while doing so.

Quebec's anti-veil fatwa won't pass the first step of the Oakes Test. Hence it won't be necessary to consider the other criteria, which it would fail as well. That's my layman's understanding. Feel free to correct any errors.

Comment: Staying together for the kids can translate as leaving them in an abusive and dysfunctional war zone. I told my mother to get a separation circa 1963, when I was 9. She didn't take my advice, any more than she took the Alberta Welfare order to dump him or be cut off from welfare. She dragged us with him to BC instead. I reminded her of that recently, when she had one of my siblings tell me that she was in hospital, as a way station to living in a Seniors Care facility.

I came across the idea of Kids divorcing parents in a Robert Heinlein "Juvenile" SF novel when I was 11. The protagonist's girl friend is an emancipated minor living in the county home for children who have divorced their parents.

I made plans to leave and did so when I was 16. The Rural BC School District my dysfunctional parents lived in didn't have grade 12. The counsellor arranged for the $85 room & board subsidy cheques be sent directly to me, not to my parents. "Mom" didn't even ask how I would pay for the R&B.

Comment: Transparency is already available in the form of CPT codes used by the medical field.  For example, a visit to Ophthalmologist requiring "Anesthesia for procedures on eye; lens surgery" - CPT code is 00142.  31500 pertains to "A laryngoscope is passed into the hypopharynx and the glottis and vocal cords are visualized............." (The cpt code description is much more detailed).  There are literally hundreds of codes used for each procedure or event involved in the treatment and care of a patient.  What I don't understand, however, is the fact that Sky Ridge and Med Center of Aurora are owned by the same group, but the costs for all CPT codes are much higher at Sky Ridge.  In many cases the same doctor with privileges at both facilities will charge different fees for the same CPT activity.

Comment: If we had a free market in drugs, there would be hundreds if not thousands of drug companies. Unfortunately FDA regulations ensure that it cost more than $1 billion and 7 – 10 years to get a new drug through the FDA approval process. If a business doesn’t have $1 billion to put at risk over 7 – 10 years, they can’t enter the market. The FDA has effectively outlawed small startups from the drug market. The big drug companies love the FDA regulations because they don’t have to worry about competition from small innovative startups. Can you imagine how much suffering there would be if there was a $1 billion dollar entry fee to get into other markets? There’d be no HP, Microsoft, Google, Amazon, or Facebook for example.

Comment: Right. No discussion has occurred for raising the GET. Also, no discussion about increasing tax rebates to lower income brackets to offset the "regressiveness". Also, maybe I missed it, but I would like to see a discussion of the proportion of the total GET which is paid not by locals, but by visitors. Visitors account for maybe 10 percent of the people on island, and I am sure that they spend more per day that we do on average. Also, how much GET do we lose by another 10 percent of the population Military and Dependents who shop at commissaries? They use our facilities, but don't pay GET. These discussions about GET are misleading and incomplete. Re property tax, a lot of renters are going to pay that increase and that is regressive given the high rents on Oahu.

Comment: Are we talking about requiring a permit to operate a bicycle, or a license for the cycle itself?

And a plate would be the first thing a thief would remove (or steal from another bike to use on a stolen one), so I don't see registration as a deterrent to theft. Even when high-end bikes with unique serial numbers are registered, their recovery is given a low priority by law enforcement.

Comment: Sorry Bard, but it isn't the unions doing that. It was the legislature that decided that "young" teachers hired after June 30, 2006 have a structural incentive to leave within five years of teaching in Alaska. To actually earn a retirement under the law passed that created the 401 type pensions these teachers have they must work more than 30+ years to get a pension from Alaska. If they leave before that time they get all their own contributions back...plus or minus investment earnings or losses, but they can only get back five years of employer contributions...plus or minus earnings or losses. If someone works here for more than five years, but not long enough to retire they lose all employer contributions beyond the first five years just as surely as if they had set fire to the money.

Comment: The growth of societal adaptation to legal marijuana is as complicated as was the question of alcohol, though being compressed over a far shorter time period.  In the 1800s there were virtually no laws regulating the sale of alcohol other than paying for a city license;  Eugene's newspapers  frequently complained of the number of saloons, and drunks, to be found downtown.  
Finally in 1920 Americans were fed up with the problems of alcohol and passed prohibition.  But that didn't stop drinking, which led to speakeasies, bootleggers, backwoods revenuers  and eventually violent gangs. 
Finally in 1933 Americans became fed up with prohibition, but then followed a more gradual reintroduction with stricter laws.  We had local option to preserve choice; when I was young Oregon still didn't have "liquor by the drink" which meant you carried an OLCC card and your own bottle. 
I imagine as the world of legal marijuana evolves we'll develop similar problems, and solutions, along the way.

Comment: The examples offered by Ndlovu here ("barely walk alone at night", "drinks spiked", "man she has married", "not paid equally") are kinda vapid, actually. They do not reflect the lived reality of the majority, and they diminish the experiences of other human beings.

You don't need to be a woman to be attacked on the street at night (if it's unsafe for women, it's unsafe for everyone). Men aren't immune to rohypnol, and it's possible for men to live in fear of the women they have married - not all domestic violence is one-way. And the wage gap has been debunked elsewhere.

I think the problem is not so much that women's suffering is ignored: It's that all suffering is ignored. We collectively pretend (to ourselves and everyone) that life is okay when it's not. Most of us have suffered in some way, some more than others - and all suffering deserves to be met with compassion and understanding.

Not hashtags and shouting. That sort of activism brings us no closer together.

Comment: Having worked on many successful (meeting most of the intended goals and not having a catastrophic systems meltdown) public sector IT projects, I can say the flaws are thus: 

1) Scope: this process is usually not done well and thus the agreement on goals is not clear. 
2) Existing IT staff and departments feeling threatened by new tech and methods. Often they obstruct or sabotage. A room full of Windows PC guys being intimidated by a bunch of Mac newbies.
3) Budget: only a third of the budget should be spent on development: 2/3 needs to go on implementation, testing, and troubleshooting. Public sector organizations are complicted by their nature: you have to deal with deadbeat staff who have priviliges, you have to deal with complicated mandates, political interferance, political crises, etc. Not paying on time. 
4: Getting hosed: because of all the above, pretty well every private sector player has a very cynical attitude to government contracts, and basically takes them for a ride.

Comment: @ Big Glenn..not sure who "Liberal Whitey" is, but your assertion on Trudeau Sr. is not really supported by the data. This chart shows immigration (permanent residency) going back to 1860s --   http://www.cic.gc.ca/english/resources/statistics/facts2014/permanent/index.asp#figure1

[Lots of great data on that page BTW]

Post WWII the first big spike in immigration was in the 50s and early 60s, pre-Trudeau. In fact, during the PETrudeau years, (68-79) the peak was no higher than prior to Trudeau.  The real surge started, as the article accurately states in the Mulroney years, particularly in the late 80s and early 90s. 

And keep in mind that PM Harper sustained those levels of immigration for the 10 years he was in power, so both Conservative PMs have welcomed immigrants from non-European countries as well. 

Note the chart further down the page that shows that immigration as a % of total population is pretty constant since 1990 even if absolute #s have risen.

Comment: Journalists?  Columnists seem to be much more common than journalists these days. 

When was the last time you read an article that gave full, clear and detailed information, and allowed the reader to form his own opinion?  Even news articles are far more likely to espouse an opinion, and to provide only such information as will support that narrative.  Opinion, no matter how well sourced, is still opinion.  After all, the reader doesn't know what sources the writer has carefully not used.

I am also reminded of a comment that I have heard in many forms over the years - if everything is an urgent, level one, top priority emergency, then nothing is.  Put another way, if everything we read about politicians in general accuses them of being liars or unprincipled self-serving scoundrels, then that becomes normal, and it is unreasonable to expect people to take notice of the latest scandal involving the latest scoundrel.

Comment: Really?  Sustainable worlds?  There's $247 Trillion of debt in this world and only 35% of that in money supply.  How in the hell is that sustainable?  if there were a way to tax 100% of the money in the world (there isn't), it would barely cover a third of the debt.

How does the world situation correct back to rationality?  A period of Deflation in which all assets values -- stocks, bonds, and real estate -- drop about 70% in value, while cash increases 300% in value.  Of course, that probably means Depression over most of the planet.

Why did John Maynard Keynes say, "In the long run, we're all dead?"  That was in answer to the question of who deals with all this debt in the long run?  From his perspective, he was right.  He's dead and can't be held accountable for the position he's left today's young people in, responsible for paying debt they didn't incur or benefit from.

They should put every Progressive before a firing squad.

Comment: Per the St Louis Fed the median income for an individual American in 2016 was $31k. For me, rich would be someone who earns seven times that, or $217k. For a decent rate, I’d say that those earning less than the annual poverty income of $14k shouldn’t be taxed. Those earning the median should be taxed about what they’re taxed now, 15% on income above $14k, or $2.6k on someone who earns the median. Then, increase the marginal rate by 7% for every multiple of the median income, so someone earning $217k would be paying 64% on any income above that. Interest, dividends, capital gains, and estates are all considered income, no preferential rates for the owners of capital or wealthy inheritors - they should pay taxes just like the rest of us.

Micronesians and others that find their way to our shores are really economic and environmental refugees. If population grows another 20% or 25% (currently at about 1.5 million) in the foreseeable future the State could have approximately 2 million people. Then what?  Hunger, disease, poor sanitation, lack of water, deadlier storms, longer summers, shorter winters...and heat.  Lots of heat.  Homelessness will not be an issue.  Survival will be a challenge.  Things are not always going to be the same.  Change is not linear it can be and often is exponential.  We build and plan our communities for 50 or 60 years.  That worked in the 20th Century.  That will not work anymore.  Need to change course now.  Don't want to be a pessimist.  But the numbers are very telling.

Comment: We need an income tax to pay for basic services. Here is just a sample of what I consider basic services: getting roads plowed in our neighborhoods and having snow removed in our cul-de-sacs and sidewalks on a timely basis; enable schools to provide basic school supplies and not ask parents to buy $150 of supplies at the start of the school year; build and repair roads and bridges in the summertime; provide public transportation. Improved library services and enhanced funding for colleges to maintain and grow its programming. Let's attract talent! This is what makes a place livable. And these expenses are just for the cities. The people off the road system have their own needs that also must be provided for. A graduated income tax is fair. A sales tax is not -- a single mother making $20,000 a year feels a 5% (or whatever percent) tax on a purchase a lot more than someone making $60,000 a year. We used to have an income tax and a school tax, and no dividend. The free ride is over.

Comment: SS,  My 401Ks were extremely lucrative for us because I learned some basic investing rules. Our traditional IRA were right for us at the time but we have been converting them to Roth IRAs for about 16 years and will have the conversions completed in another 2-3 years. Back to those basic investing rules I learned on my own by reading and watching shows like the "Nightly Business Report" on PBS. My taxable investments have also been very lucrative for us. Here is one "aha investment moment" for me that I will gladly share with everyone, "Dividend Reinvestment Plans (DRP)". If the one you're researching charges you ANY fees, move on, you can find a better DRP. Some DRPs will even give you up to a 5% discount on stock purchases. Wealth accumulation is a life long and long term process for the vast, vast majority of us. I never took a business or investing class beyond what was required of me to graduate from Willamette High School.

Freedom can be a scary thing for individuals.

Comment: My mouth is agape at your reply, my friend, seriously.

The formal magisterium is not in the business of passing judgement of scriptural interpretations per se. Instead it simply uses scripture in its pronouncements, and that regularly implies an interpretation. Problem for your view is that the Catholic approach to interpreting scripture has changed over time, and the magisterium's use of scripture changes along with scriptural scholarship. Typology and allegory were once all the rage; then there was literalism tainted by a ruthless effort to force complementarity out of outright contradictions (that got us, for instance, the attempt to use Joshua's sun standing still to deny astronomical discoveries). 

I suggest Tridentinus, that perhaps when you think of modern scripture scholarship, you are thinking about the very real battles that exist among scholars, and some of the way-out-nonsense that some bring to the subject. Scholarly debate sorts that stuff out over time, as in science.

Comment: You end this post with "Aloha," yet there is clearly no Aloha in your accusations, which are misinformed and offensive.  Do you know anything about the NOAA Fisheries Observer Program?  I suggest you call up John Kelley, the Pacific Islands Regional Office Administrator for the program and talk story with him about what it is the NOAA Fisheries Observer Program does.  FYI: the Observer Program is responsible for one of the only and the largest, most comprehensive data sets on the pelagic fisheries of this region that exists. They are the technicians on the ground who collect all of the data that then goes in to stock assessments - the basis of the entire scientific process for these fisheries.  Furthermore you are misinformed about the nature of the Hawaiian Longline Fishery and where "the scientists" stand - if you ask any Fisheries Scientist at NOAA, they will tell you it is one of most (and best) regulated and sustainable commercial fisheries in the world.

Comment: "It was and is our oil."
This is the great leftist/environmentalist lie; the oil from which we derive revenue is NOT our oil because we sold it to the producers.   We sold the leases to the main Prudhoe Bay province in 1968 for, IIRC, $968 Million, the right to tax property and income, and a 12.5% share of the oil recovered as royalty in kind, which they pump and transport for us, though we do pay a tariff on the transportation.   Since that lease was signed it has been the producers' oil except for the royalty oil that Alaska sells on the open market and keeps the profit as State revenue.

Comment: Considering it's proximity to DIA, planes would still be much more of a noise nuisance than a racetrack. But to get attendance it has to be closer to a large population area, unlike the former PPIR in Fountain. Nice track, not a good location. This proposal is for near DIA and I-70, not too distant for travellers to go out of the way, still close to the Denver area's potential fanbase, and close to the mountains for family trips. 

I went to the Vegas race awhile back and had a Hot Pass.... access to the pits and garage is way cool. No other sport has a fan experience like NASCAR races. Even without a pit pass. 

The noise comparison to Bandimere has flaws. Bandimere is tucked against the foothills and the noise bounces away from them. It won't spread and dissipate like a flat area. Drag cars are also much louder than stock cars. 

If it's done right, I hope it's built. Several forms of racing, even local events, could be held. Just one thing... no 1.5 mi. cookie cutter track.

Comment: I hope the debate about whether arrearage is a partisan issue can finally be put to rest. As I have stated before, it definitely is not, and assertions to the contrary are a distraction. As to arrearage being moot, that is not the case because arrearage is only one of the issues around trust lands management that the TLAC is looking at. These include low reforestation levels and a lack of a usable forest inventory (meaning the DNR hasn't measured and therefore isn't sure what kind and how many trees are in the county forests it manages). Also, reconveyance was removed as an alternative because it would require an act of the state legislature, a ponderous undertaking. 

The charge of the TLAC is to make recommendations about how best to manage county trust lands. Arrearage is just one part of this.

Comment: A general call for kindness in society is certainly welcome, but what we're talking about here is how our shared tax dollars get spent, which is another kettle of fish. We can all be kind to each other and yet still recognize that our public services have to be shared by all, equal to all, and neutral by definition.  

Accommodation often spirals out of control.  Look at the US and how lawsuits against state governments forced holiday displays to be opened to multiple faiths.  Pretty soon they had aluminum poles for TV fabrications like Festivus next to legitimate faiths, and even the odd Satanist display.  Once you open the door to everyone, you open the door to EVERYONE.

Neutrality is accomplished by denying everyone equally, or allowing everyone equally ... and that's it. The latter gets really messy, really quickly. The fact we're all here debating is proof of it!

Comment: Another reader:  RE:  the world market will go elsewhere for lower prices as farmed fishing grows.

I am currently on an extended fishing trip to Costa Rica and having talked to the Boat Captains here as well as a couple of the fish market owners I find I quite agree with you.  They estimate that 80% to 90% of Alaskan fish sales have gone over to fish farmed Salmon in just the last 5 years.  The few who are still buying the fresh fish at current prices are the tourists and ex-pats who live down here and can afford it.  With fish farms sales having been down here for some years now the people who live here are already used to the idea of buying by price alone and the bottom line is that Iceland farmed Salmon is noticeably less than fresh from Alaska salmon.  Additionally, when heavily spiced up as they tend to do down here in Latin America, I defy anyone to tell the difference between farmed and fresh.

1) Drug costs in Canada are higher than most OECD countries because they are based on the cost in a basket of countries of which one is the US, which is substantially higher than anywhere else.

Comment: My grandmother's Edison "Model C" phonograph sits in the corner of our living-room, on top of the HiFi system that none of my grandchildren know how to work. It was made in 1910 and plays black, cylindrical records that play for two minutes each. It replaced an earlier version that used incompatible brown wax cylinders.  Shortly after my grandmother bought it (for today's equivalent of over $1,000 ) Edison came out with a superior model that played four minute "Blue Amberol" cylinders, which were incompatible with the two minute machines. Shortly after that the gramophone was invented, which played flat round records 1/4" thick and revolved at 78 revs per minute.....

I think my grandmother would sympathize, Margaret!  

PS - don't worry about the dreams. Those young whipper-snappers have no chance of taking over your job!

Comment: Continued from previous post.....

You see, stock market crashes are a normal part of investing, and some of us with long term mindsets know that in a year or two the stock market will be churning up again and most if not all the losses recouped.  Just because the market crashes people still have loans they are paying, they still have to heat and power their home, they still have cell phones and gas to put in their cars etc. etc. etc.  Life goes on, and so do profits at these great companies.

I use this example a lot but here goes again.  This fall the Bank of Montreal will celebrate their 200th year in business.  Yes, 1817 to now.  In 1829 they started making dividend payments, and have not missed one since.  188 years of consecutive dividend payments.  Through two world wars, and EVERY single crash you mentioned and more, they kept churning out cash to their shareholders.  Do you really think this will change?  ALL the Canadian banks have similar stories.

Continued again.........
